title: As K-pop superstars BTS return, HYBE CEO to test ‘scarcity’ model for fandom business - Music Business Worldwide
raw_content: As K-pop superstars BTS return, HYBE CEO to test ‘scarcity’ model for fandom business - Music Business Worldwide                                  Music Business Worldwide News Interviews  All Interviews Inspiring Women World’s Greatest Managers World’s Greatest Producers World’s Greatest Songwriters World Leaders  Analysis  All Analysis MBW Explains MBW Reacts MBW Views Stat Of The Week  Database Podcast Jobs MBW+  Subscribe Login As K-pop superstars BTS return, HYBE CEO to test ‘scarcity’ model for fandom business  January 14, 2026By Daniel TencerBTSHYBE, the South Korean entertainment giant behind BTS – arguably the world’s biggest K-pop act – is planning to spend 2026 developing “a new experience model based on scarcity,” according to company CEO Jason Jaesang Lee.Continue to article...“Scarcity is an important element that enhances the added value of the fan experience,” Lee said in a New Year address to HYBE staff, as reported in media sources in South Korea.“To innovate future fandom businesses, we will design and test an integrated online and offline experience model based on scarcity.” Lee seemingly offered few other details on what the “scarcity” model might look like. Fewer concerts and appearances? VIP-only access to events? Limited access to new releases? But one thing is certain: Increased scarcity drives up prices, and that means potential new revenue growth opportunities.Whatever HYBE’s plans may be, Lee’s scarcity philosophy is about to be tested with the return of BTS, the global superstar K-pop boy group that has been quite scarce for the past four years as its members completed mandatory military training.HYBE on Tuesday (January 13) officially unveiled tour dates for BTS’s first world tour in four years, set to begin on April 9 with a three-night engagement at Goyang Stadium near Seoul. The tour will span five continents with 79 shows in 34 markets.That follows last week’s announcement that a new BTS album will land on March 20. In what might be a taste of one element of HYBE’s ‘scarcity’ model, members of BTS’ fan club, ARMY, will have access to a ticket presale for 36 of the shows starting on January 22. Two more Los Angeles shows will be available to ARMY members on January 23. The tour’s general onsale will begin January 24 at LiveNation.com.With BTS out of the limelight for four years, HYBE has become less reliant on the superstar group for its revenue, and while the BTS boys were busy with their military training, HYBE was busy with major expansions in the US, Latin America, and Africa.That has included major investments into the acquisition of local music labels and the establishment of new global musical acts like KATSEYE (formed in partnership with Universal Music Group‘s Geffen Records). In 2026, CEO Lee told HYBE staff, the company aims to turn those investments into profit.“To innovate future fandom businesses, we will design and test an integrated online and offline experience model based on scarcity.”Jason Jaesang Lee, HYBEIt has also meant the development of Weverse, HYBE’s platform for superfans that has been attracting Western artists with the promise of a stronger connection with fans and new monetization opportunities.2026 will be the year HYBE needs to show those investments were worthwhile, Lee told HYBE staff in his address.“We need to prove the justification for investment in new businesses and artist IP where preemptive investment has been made,” he said, as quoted by Chosun Daily.“We have confirmed meaningful traffic expansion so far, and now we must transition to a phase of valid revenue generation to be confident in sustainable business viability,” Lee said, adding that “when investment shows results, new investment gains legitimacy and a virtuous cycle of growth is established.” Saying that securing profitability is HYBE’s top priority for 2026, Lee laid out five tasks he says HYBE has to accomplish this year, per Asia Business Daily:verifying the viability of new businesses and IPestablishing the sustainability of IP and expanding the fan base through “innovation we haven’t tried”designing a new experience model based on scarcitysecuring leadership in the AI-based prosumer marketimplementing true global governanceLee said this marks the “realization” of the plans laid out under the HYBE 2.0 strategy that he announced shortly after being appointed CEO in 2024. The mid- and long-term strategy involves shifting the company from its initial “label-solution-platform” structure to a “music-platform-tech” structure.So far, the “music” part of the new structure has seen, among other things, the reorganization of HYBE’s labels in South Korea and Japan under the new HYBE Music Group APAC; the “platform” part has seen the continued expansion of features on the Weverse platform; and the “tech” part has HYBE exploring and investing in new AI-driven technologies.“If 2025 was a year of investment to lay the groundwork for ‘HYBE 2.0,’ then 2026 will mark the beginning of visible results. This year, we will prove to the market that our bold investments were the right direction,” Lee said in his New Year’s address.Yet for fans, the largest change at HYBE this year will no doubt be the return of BTS, a musical phenomenon so strongly linked to HYBE’s fortunes that the company’s stock plummeted when BTS announced their hiatus back in 2022. The stock then rallied in the summer of 2025 when BTS members appeared together at HYBE HQ with a “we are back” banner in the background.Yet, as Lee’s message indicates, the HYBE of today is moving beyond being “the label behind BTS,” and even moving beyond K-pop itself.“HYBE’s growth philosophy is clear: to create top-tier IP, lead the fandom business, and expand those results into new markets and genres,” Lee said.In the meantime, the music industry will be watching closely to see just how HYBE’s “scarcity” strategy pans out.Music Business WorldwideNews South Korea BTS HYBE 2.0 Jason Jaesang Lee scarcity world tourRelated Posts  Ticketmaster faces fine in Mexico over BTS concert sale  BTS strike Netflix deal to livestream comeback concert, followed by documentary about making of new album  HYBE cashes out $3.5m worth of shares, riding on BTS comeback  BTS to officially return on March 20 with new album; tease first world tour in four years        Latest Music Industry JobsCommercial Promotions Partnerships ManagerNew York, United States  SpotifySenior Director, Strategy + Business DevelopmentNew York, United States  Sony Music EntertainmentDirector Revenue AssuranceBerlin  BMGArtist ManagerModest! The Business Strategy Behind HYBE
December 15, 2025
By SimpleKorea

HYBE is not structured like a traditional K-pop entertainment company. 
Its core strategy is to separate artists from platforms, and then scale both independently. 
This is what allowed HYBE to grow from a single-group agency into a global entertainment corporation.

Contents
Toggle
1) From Idol Agency to IP Company2) Multi-Label System, Not a Single Factory3) Platform Ownership Through Weverse4) Direct-to-Fan Monetization5) Global Expansion by Acquisition, Not Export6) Artist-Centric Long-Term Planning7) Technology as a Core CompetencyThe Strategic Core
1) From Idol Agency to IP Company

HYBE’s first strategic shift was redefining idols as intellectual property (IP) rather than short-term music acts. 
Music is only one output. 
Albums, concerts, merchandise, documentaries, games, and characters all extend the same IP.
This reduces dependency on chart performance and creates recurring revenue streams that last beyond peak popularity.

2) Multi-Label System, Not a Single Factory

HYBE operates through independent labels such as BigHit Music, PLEDIS, ADOR, BELIFT LAB, and others. 
Each label maintains creative autonomy while sharing infrastructure.
This avoids creative bottlenecks and reduces risk. 
If one label underperforms, the overall system remains stable.

3) Platform Ownership Through Weverse

Weverse is central to HYBE’s strategy. 
Unlike social media platforms owned by third parties, Weverse allows HYBE to control fan data, communication, commerce, and content distribution.
Fans do not just follow artists. 
They exist inside HYBE’s ecosystem. 
This strengthens retention and monetization while reducing reliance on external platforms.

4) Direct-to-Fan Monetization

HYBE prioritizes direct fan relationships over intermediaries. 
Memberships, exclusive content, paid live streams, and merchandise are integrated into a single funnel.
This model increases margins and makes revenue more predictable, especially during periods without music releases.

5) Global Expansion by Acquisition, Not Export

Rather than only exporting K-pop, HYBE acquires and partners with existing global companies. 
HYBE America, HYBE Japan, and acquisitions like Ithaca Holdings allowed instant access to local markets, talent, and industry networks.
This is faster and less risky than building from scratch.

6) Artist-Centric Long-Term Planning

HYBE invests heavily in artist sustainability. 
This includes mental health resources, flexible career paths, and solo or sub-unit expansions.
The goal is longevity. 
Short-term profit is sacrificed to protect brand value over decades.

7) Technology as a Core Competency

HYBE positions itself as a tech-enabled entertainment company. 
Data analytics, fan behavior tracking, and platform optimization inform decisions on touring, releases, and content timing.
Entertainment intuition is supported by measurable signals.

The Strategic Core

HYBE’s advantage is not hit-making alone. 
It is vertical integration plus platform control, combined with decentralized creativity.
By owning the fan relationship, diversifying IP, and globalizing through infrastructure rather than trends, HYBE built a business model that can outlive any single group.
That is the real strategy behind HYBE.

How Does Hybe Company Thrive in the Global Entertainment Arena?
HYBE Corporation, the South Korean entertainment giant, has redefined the music industry, particularly with its significant influence in the K-pop world. In 2024, the company's revenue reached an impressive $1.65 billion, marking its third consecutive year exceeding $1 billion. Despite fluctuations in operating profit, the company's recent performance showcases its adaptability and robust market position. This analysis will delve into the core operations of Hybe Canvas Business Model, and explore what makes this Universal Music Group, Warner Music Group, and Live Nation Entertainment competitor tick.

Understanding the operational strategies of Hybe Company is essential for anyone interested in the entertainment sector. Hybe Corporation's innovative approach to artist management, from BTS management to developing new talent, provides a valuable case study. Furthermore, exploring Hybe Entertainment's diverse business sectors and global expansion plans offers insights into the future of the music industry and the strategies driving its success, including its impact on the K-pop industry.

What Are the Key Operations Driving Hybe’s Success?

Hybe Corporation, formerly known as Big Hit Entertainment, creates and delivers value through a multifaceted approach centered on music production, artist management, live performances, and digital content platforms. The company's core offerings include recorded music (albums and digital singles), concerts and live events, artist-related merchandise and licensing, and its proprietary fan communication platform, Weverse. These offerings primarily serve a global audience of music fans, with a strong emphasis on the K-pop demographic, but increasingly expanding to include international artists.
Operationally, Hybe Entertainment is structured around three main pillars: Music, Platform, and tech-driven future growth initiatives, a reorganization implemented in August 2024 as part of its 'HYBE 2.0' strategy. The Music pillar encompasses music production and artist management, leveraging Hybe's expertise in training, marketing, and A&R systems to develop new talent and enhance existing artists' careers. This includes managing a diverse roster of popular groups like BTS, SEVENTEEN, TXT, ENHYPEN, and NewJeans.
The Platform pillar focuses on Weverse, a comprehensive fan engagement and e-commerce platform that connects artists and fans through various features, including direct messaging, exclusive content, and merchandise sales. Weverse had 9.4 million monthly active users in Q4 2024, and its lifetime downloads reached 150 million in 2024. Hybe's integrated '360-degree business model' spans the entire artist lifecycle from discovery and training to content creation, distribution, and fan engagement.

Music Production and Artist Management

Hybe excels in developing and managing artists, particularly within the K-pop industry. They utilize a comprehensive system for artist training, marketing, and A&R. This approach allows them to effectively nurture and promote both established and emerging talent, ensuring sustained success and innovation in the music market.

Platform and Fan Engagement

Weverse is a crucial platform for Hybe, fostering direct artist-fan interaction. The platform includes features like direct messaging, exclusive content, and merchandise sales. This creates a loyal fan base and drives revenue through various channels, which is a key aspect of Hybe's business model.

Live Performances and Events

Live concerts and events are significant revenue drivers for Hybe. These events provide unique fan experiences and generate substantial income. The company's ability to produce high-quality live shows contributes significantly to its overall financial performance and brand recognition.

Merchandise and Licensing

Merchandise and licensing are essential components of Hybe’s revenue model. By offering artist-related merchandise, the company capitalizes on fan enthusiasm and brand loyalty. This strategy supplements income from music sales and live events, providing a diversified revenue stream.

Key Operational Strategies

Hybe’s operational uniqueness lies in its integrated '360-degree business model,' which spans the entire artist lifecycle from discovery and training to content creation, distribution, and fan engagement. This model, coupled with its multi-label system, allows for diversified artist portfolios and sustained growth even with the temporary hiatus of major acts. The company's supply chain involves extensive partnerships for music distribution, concert production, and merchandise manufacturing. Its global distribution networks are continuously expanding, with strategic moves into the U.S., Japan, and Latin American markets. To understand how Hybe competes in the market, check out the Competitors Landscape of Hybe.

Multi-Label System: Diversifies artist portfolios and mitigates risks.
Global Expansion: Strategic moves into key markets like the U.S., Japan, and Latin America.
Integrated Business Model: Manages the entire artist lifecycle, from training to fan engagement.
Technological Integration: Leverages platforms like Weverse for direct fan interaction and e-commerce.

How Does Hybe Make Money?

The Hybe Corporation, a leading K-pop agency, employs a multifaceted approach to generate revenue. Their strategy encompasses both direct and indirect artist involvement, reflecting a comprehensive entertainment ecosystem. This integrated model allows for diverse income streams and robust financial performance.
For the fiscal year 2024, Hybe Corporation achieved record consolidated revenue, demonstrating strong growth. The company's ability to leverage its artists across various platforms and ventures is key to its financial success. This diversification helps mitigate risks and capitalize on emerging opportunities within the entertainment industry.
In 2024, Hybe's consolidated revenue reached KRW 2.2545 trillion (approximately $1.654 billion USD), marking a 3.5% increase year-on-year. In Q1 2025, the company reported record sales of KRW 500.6 billion ($348 million), a 38.7% year-on-year increase.

Revenue Streams Breakdown

The revenue streams are categorized into 'artist direct-involvement' and 'artist indirect-involvement'. The 'artist direct-involvement' segment includes revenue from recorded music, concerts, commercials, and artist appearances. The 'artist indirect-involvement' segment encompasses merchandising, licensing, and the Weverse superfan platform.

Artist Direct-Involvement: This segment generated KRW 1.445 trillion ($1.06 billion) in 2024, a slight decrease of 1.8% year-on-year. Concert revenue saw a significant surge, jumping 25.6% year-on-year in 2024 to KRW 450.87 billion ($330.69 million), and more than tripling in Q1 2025 to KRW 155.2 billion.

Artist Indirect-Involvement: This segment saw revenues jump 14.5% year-on-year to KRW 809.29 billion ($593.56 million) in 2024. Merchandise and licensing revenue specifically increased by 29.1% to KRW 420 billion ($293.4 million) in 2024.

Merchandise and Licensing: In Q1 2025, merchandise and licensing revenue reached KRW 106.4 billion ($74 million), a 75% year-on-year jump.

Fan Club Revenue: Fan club revenue, which includes Weverse, grew by 39% year-on-year in Q1 2025 to KRW 30.5 billion ($21 million). Weverse introduced a subscription-based membership in Q4 2024.

Which Strategic Decisions Have Shaped Hybe’s Business Model?

Hybe Corporation, formerly known as Big Hit Entertainment, has undergone significant transformations, marked by strategic moves and key milestones. The company's evolution reflects its ambition to become a global entertainment and media powerhouse, expanding beyond its origins in music. This journey has involved strategic acquisitions, restructuring initiatives, and a focus on technological innovation.

A pivotal moment for the Hybe Company was its rebranding in 2021, signaling a strategic shift towards a broader entertainment scope. This was quickly followed by the acquisition of Ithaca Holdings, which brought prominent artists into its portfolio and marked a significant entry into the U.S. market. These moves set the stage for further expansion and diversification.

In 2024, Hybe Entertainment initiated 'HYBE 2.0,' a major restructuring designed to enhance content quality and expand global operations. The company reorganized its core business areas and is preparing to launch new ventures in key markets like Latin America and India. This strategic realignment aims to foster synergies and drive future growth.

Key Milestones

The rebranding from Big Hit Entertainment to HYBE Corporation in 2021. The acquisition of Ithaca Holdings, including artists like Justin Bieber and Ariana Grande. The restructuring initiative 'HYBE 2.0' in 2024, focusing on global expansion and content enhancement.

Strategic Moves

Expanding beyond music into a broader entertainment and media company. Entering the U.S. market through strategic acquisitions. Reorganizing business areas to enhance content and expand globally. Launching new ventures in key markets like Latin America and India.

Competitive Edge

Robust multi-label system allowing for a diverse artist roster and global success. Proprietary superfan platform, Weverse, fostering deep fan engagement and revenue generation. Exploration of ventures in AI, audio/voice technology, and gaming. Collaborations like KATSEYE with Universal Music Group to export K-pop methodology.

Financial Performance

2024 saw a 37.5% drop in operating profit and a net loss due to BTS hiatus and investments. Q1 2025 showed a substantial rebound with a 50% year-on-year rise in operating profit and a nearly 400% surge in net profit. Weverse's user base grew by 19% in 2024, reaching 150 million cumulative global downloads.

Operational Challenges and Adaptations

In 2024, Hybe Corporation faced challenges, including a 37.5% drop in operating profit and a net loss, primarily due to BTS's hiatus and investments in new businesses. Despite these challenges, the company demonstrated resilience. The Q1 2025 performance showed a significant recovery, driven by concert revenue and strategic adjustments.

The company's multi-label system has allowed artists like SEVENTEEN, ENHYPEN, and NewJeans to achieve global success.
Weverse's user base grew to 150 million cumulative global downloads in 2024.

Hybe's expansion includes plans to launch HYBE Latin America in 2025 and enter India in the second half of 2025.
The company is exploring ventures in generative AI, audio/voice technology, and gaming.

How Is Hybe Positioning Itself for Continued Success?

Hybe Corporation, a leading force in the global entertainment industry, particularly in the K-pop sector, navigates a landscape of intense competition. The company strategically employs a 'multi-home, multi-genre' approach to solidify its dominance, integrating K-pop systems with local cultures across diverse markets. With a strong roster of artists and a robust fan engagement platform, Hybe Entertainment is positioned for sustained growth.
Despite its robust market position, Hybe faces significant risks, including reliance on its top artists, particularly BTS. Internal conflicts and legal challenges also pose threats. Furthermore, geopolitical instability and economic downturns in key markets could impact consumer spending on entertainment, affecting the company's financial performance.

Industry Position

Hybe Corporation holds a leading position in the global entertainment industry, especially in the K-pop sector. Its 'multi-home, multi-genre' strategy aims to integrate K-pop with local cultures. Hybe's strong artist roster and fan loyalty contribute significantly to its market share.

Risks

Hybe faces risks such as heavy reliance on top artists, particularly BTS, whose hiatus for military service impacted profits. Declining revenue from recorded music and internal conflicts also pose challenges. Geopolitical instability and legal issues add further risks.

Future Outlook

Hybe is pursuing strategic initiatives to sustain and expand profitability. The 'HYBE 2.0' strategy focuses on enhancing the music business and platform capabilities. Expansion into new markets and artist diversification are key to future growth.

Key Strategies

The company plans to expand its global footprint with new artists debuting in Japan and Latin America in 2025, and a confirmed expansion into India in the second half of 2025. Continued positive earnings for Q2 2025 are anticipated, fueled by upcoming artist activities and the expected return of BTS.

Strategic Initiatives and Growth

Hybe's 'HYBE 2.0' strategy launched in August 2024, aims to enhance its music business and platform capabilities, and invest in tech-driven future growth initiatives. The company is expanding globally with new artists and markets.

Expansion into Japan, Latin America, and India.
Focus on tech-driven growth initiatives like gaming and AI.
Anticipated positive earnings in Q2 2025.
Continued diversification of artist portfolio and fan engagement.

The company's Weverse platform achieved 150 million cumulative global downloads by 2024, with a 19% user growth, strengthening its global reach. The decline in revenue from recorded music and physical album sales saw an 11.3% drop in 2024. The return of BTS members in the second half of 2025 is expected to boost profitability.
